articles.headline: New Scrutiny for In-House Financial Court as Banker Faces Ban
articles.snippet: Critics say internal financial courts tip the scales against the defendants.
articles.abstract: Critics say internal financial courts tip the scales against the defendants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a former Goldman Sachs executive was found to have mishandled confidential information in connection with an embarrassing leak at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the decision did not come in a typical court of law.

articles.headline: Identity Thieves Hijack Cellphone Accounts to Go After Virtual Currency
articles.snippet: So-called phone porting attacks are exposing a vulnerability that could be exploited against anybody with valuable emails or other digital files.
articles.abstract: So-called phone porting attacks are exposing a vulnerability that could be exploited against anybody with valuable emails or other digital files.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hackers have discovered that one of the most central elements of online security — the mobile phone number — is also one of the easiest to steal.

articles.headline: Angry Trump Grilled His Generals About Troop Increase, Then Gave In
articles.snippet: The president, who had called for American withdrawal from Afghanistan before he took office, in the end accepted a “big military” approach as the only viable option.
articles.abstract: The president, who had called for American withdrawal from Afghanistan before he took office, in the end accepted a “big military” approach as the only viable option.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s skepticism about America’s involvement in Afghanistan was no secret to his staff. But his top national security officials were still taken aback at a meeting in the Situation Room on July 19, when an angry Mr. Trump began ripping apart their latest proposal to send thousands of additional American troops to the country.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Even Business Leaders Who Abandoned Trump’s Councils May Not Stray Far
articles.snippet: Despite their symbolic moves, many C.E.O.s will continue to advocate positions in person and through lobbyists, while people in Mr. Trump’s inner circle face a harder decision.
articles.abstract: Despite their symbolic moves, many C.E.O.s will continue to advocate positions in person and through lobbyists, while people in Mr. Trump’s inner circle face a harder decision.

articles.headline: Trump Outlines New Afghanistan War Strategy With Few Details
articles.snippet: The president embraced deepened American involvement in a nearly 16-year-old war, but he did not say how many troops would be committed or how he would judge success.
articles.abstract: The president embraced deepened American involvement in a nearly 16-year-old war, but he did not say how many troops would be committed or how he would judge success.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump put forward on Monday a long-awaited strategy for resolving the nearly 16-year-old conflict in Afghanistan, but he declined to specify either the number of troops that would be committed, or the conditions by which he would judge the success of their mission there.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Mark Landler

articles.headline: China, Like U.S., Struggles to Revive Industrial Heartland
articles.snippet: Shenyang boomed during the country’s go-go years. But when the investment binge fizzled, the city and its factories sputtered.
articles.abstract: Shenyang boomed during the country’s go-go years. But when the investment binge fizzled, the city and its factories sputtered.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENYANG, China — The hulking, brown-brick industrial plants lining the roads were once the backbone of this gritty city. Today, they are outdated and unwanted, and the region is one of the Chinese economy’s most troubled.

articles.headline: Portugal Dominated Angola for Centuries. Now the Roles Are Reversed.
articles.snippet: Money flowing into Portugal is coming from a former colony. And while Angola is often cited for corruption, Portugal has been singled out for its laxness in reining in money laundering.
articles.abstract: Money flowing into Portugal is coming from a former colony. And while Angola is often cited for corruption, Portugal has been singled out for its laxness in reining in money laundering.
articles.lead_paragraph: LISBON — How the roles have reversed: The colonizer, some Portuguese contend, has been colonized.

articles.headline: Commander of Naval Fleet Relieved of Duty After Collisions
articles.snippet: Divers found the remains of missing sailors in a search of the Navy destroyer John S. McCain that collided with an oil tanker on Monday near Singapore.
articles.abstract: Divers found the remains of missing sailors in a search of the Navy destroyer John S. McCain that collided with an oil tanker on Monday near Singapore.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two days after ordering a rare suspension of ship operations worldwide, the Navy relieved the commander of the fleet that had sustained four accidents in Asia and the deaths of more than a dozen sailors this year.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Richard C. Paddock

articles.headline: At Rally, Trump Blames Media for Country’s Deepening Divisions
articles.snippet: In freewheeling remarks, President Trump abandoned a theme of national unity to focus on the news media that he said “are trying to take away our history and our heritage.”
articles.abstract: In freewheeling remarks, President Trump abandoned a theme of national unity to focus on the news media that he said “are trying to take away our history and our heritage.”
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — President Trump, stung by days of criticism that he sowed racial division in the United States after deadly clashes in Charlottesville, Va., accused the news media on Tuesday of misrepresenting what he insisted was his prompt, unequivocal condemnation of bigotry and hatred.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Labor Wants to Make Nafta Its Friend. Here’s the Problem.
articles.snippet: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is pushing for a living-wage clause in the trade pact, but mandating Mexico’s standard of living is unlikely to save American jobs.
articles.abstract: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is pushing for a living-wage clause in the trade pact, but mandating Mexico’s standard of living is unlikely to save American jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can Nafta be re-engineered to raise workers’ wages?
